decision_conditions: The Oak and Beech trees form a boundary line between 15 and 13 Linksway. Along with other nearby trees this group helps to provide a gradual transition of mature tree cover between the dwellings in Linksway and the nearby Ruislip woods National Nature Reserve (NNR)

The trees contribute to local biodiversity, and significantly contributes to the amenity and arboreal / wooded character of the Copsewood Estate Area of Special Local Character. The trees as a group have a high amenity value.

The applicant wishes to carry out the work to reduce the risk of future damage to the property however the attached report was written in May 2003 and as they have ticked no to question 6.2 "alleged damage to property" it is believed that no damage has occurred within the last 16 years. Currently there is no scope to thin the trees crowns by as much as 30% as well as reductions back to previous points. The proposed tree work would likely remove most of the trees crowns and unnecessarily introduce multip
The removal of deadwood, dangerous / hanging branches and ivy:  This does not require the formal consent of the Council.
description: To carry out tree surgery, including a crown thin by 30% and a crown reduction back to previous points, to two oak (T1 and T5 on application), five beech (TG3 and T4 on application), a crown thin by 30%, to one beech (T2 on application), a crown thin by 20% and crown lift to 7-8m over pool area, to one Oak (T6 on application), all within Area 1, on TPO 392.
